changes.name: Third or Progressive palatalization
changes.description: The velar obstruents *k, *g, *x changed to *tˊ, *dˊ, *ś if they were immediately preceded by *i, *ī, or *j, or by sequences consisting of *i and a nasal *n

changes.name: Umlaut
changes.description: Back vowels were fronted after the palatal consonants *j, *tˊ,*dˊ, and *ś: *u > *i, *ū > *ī, *a > *e, *ā > *ē

changes.name: Monophthongization
changes.description: Tautosyllabic sequences of vowel and *w or *j were monophthongized: *aw, *āw, *ew, *ēw > *ọ̄; *aj, *āj > *ē; *ej, *ēj > *ẹ̄ > *ī

changes.name: Depalatalization
changes.description: *ē was backened to *ā after the palatal consonants *j, *č, *dž, *š, *tˊ, *dˊ, *ś

changes.name: w-prothesis before *u-, *ū-
changes.description: Word-initial *u-, *ū- received a prothetic glide *w: *u-, *ū- > *wu-, *wū-

changes.name: The change *w > *β
changes.description: The bilabial glide *w changed to the bilabial fricative *β

changes.name: Socond regressive palatalization
changes.description: The velar obstruents *k, *g, *x changed to *tˊ, *dˊ, *ś if they were immediately followed by a front vowel resulting from monophthongization or by a sequence consisting of *w and a front vowel resulting from monophthongization

changes.name: The first l-epenthesis
changes.description: A lateral *l was inserted between the labial consonants *p, *b, *m, *w and an immediately following glide *j

changes.name: The change of *ś to *s'
changes.description: Palatal *ś resulting from one of the two Common Slavic palatalizations (§§ 1, 8) changed to palatalized *s

changes.name: The first liquid metathesis
changes.description: Tautosyllabic word-initial sequences *ar˙-, *al˙- bearing the acute tone changed to *rā˙, *lā˙

changes.name: Meillet's metatony
changes.description: The acute tone was dropped on unaccented syllables except for the first post-tonic syllable

changes.name: Dybo's law
changes.description: The accent shifted one syllable to the right from non-acute syllables

changes.name: The change of *kt to *k't'
changes.description: The sequence *kt changed to *k't' unless it was immediately followed by a back vowel

changes.name: The change of *kt, *xt to *t
changes.description: The sequences *kt, *xt lost their velar component and changed to *t

changes.name: Delabialization *ū > *ȳ
changes.description: The long high back vowel *ū was delabialized to *ȳ

changes.name: Assibilation of *tˊ to *c and of *dˊ to *dz
changes.description: The palatals *tˊ and *dˊ, resulting from the Third and the Second palatalizations, assibilated to *c and *dz, respectively

changes.name: Raising of *ō to *ū
changes.description: The long vowel *ō, resulting from the monophthongization of *aw, *āw, *ew, *ēw, was raised to *ū

changes.name: The change of *dž to *ž
changes.description: The affricate *dž, resulting from the pre-Proto-Slavic First palatalization, changed to *ž

changes.name: The change of *tl, *dl to *l
changes.description: In sequences of dental plosives and laterals, the plosives were lost: *tl, *dl > *l

changes.name: The second liquid metathesis
changes.description: Tautosyllabic sequences of non-high vowel + liquid that had not been affected by the first liquid metathesis (§ 10) were metathesized: *ar, *er, *al, *el > *rā, *rē, *lā, *lē

changes.name: j-prothesis
changes.description: Word-initial vowels *ā, *e, *ē,  and *i received a prothetic glide *j

changes.name: Shortening of tautosyllabic sequences *ān, *ēn to *an, *en
changes.description: Non-high long vowels were shortened before tautosyllabic *n: *ān, *ēn > *an, *en

changes.name: The change of *a to *o
changes.description: Short *a changed to *o

changes.name: The change of *ē to *ě̄
changes.description: Long *ē changed to *ě̄ (Jat)

changes.name: The change of *i to *ь and of *u to *ъ
changes.description: The short high vowels *i and *u changed to the so-called jers *ь and *ъ, respectively

changes.name: The first jer-epenthesis
changes.description: A jer (*ъ, *ь) was inserted into word-final sequences of consonant + sonorant + jer

changes.name: The rise of syllabice liquids
changes.description: Tautosyllabic sequences *ъr, *ьr, *ъl, *ьl changed to long syllabic liquids *r̥̄, *l̥̄, and tautosyllabic sequences *rъ, *rь, *lъ *lь changed to short syllabic liquids r̥, *l̥ (in examples, the underscore ring "˳" is written only if it does not colide with other diacritics)

changes.name: The rise of nasal vowels
changes.description: Tautosyllabic sequences of front vowel + nasal consonant changed to *ę̄ and tautosyllabic sequences of back vowel + nasal consonant change to *ǭ: *en, *eń, *em, *ьn, *ьń, *ьm > *ę̄; *on, *oń, *om, *ъn, *ъń, *ъm > *ǭ

changes.name: Lengthening of short vowels in unaccented word forms
changes.description: In unaccented word forms, short vowels were lengthened before word-final syllables ending in a jer (*ъ, *ь)

changes.name: Accentuation of unaccented word forms
changes.description: Unaccented word forms received an accent on their first syllable; if the word form was preceived by proclitics, the first syllable of the accentual unit received the accent; if the word form was followed by an enclitic, the enclitic received the accent regardless of whether it was preceded by proclitics

changes.name: Shortening of word-final long vowels
changes.description: Word-final long vowels were shortened

changes.name: Vowel contraction
changes.description: Two vowels which were separated from each other by the glide *j and had the same height or a height that differed by one degree (there were for degrees of vowel height at the relevant stage) merged into a long vowel; an acute tone on the first of the contracted syllables was lost; if the second of the contracted syllables was accented the resulting long vowel received a neo-acute tone which in the present study is marked by a mid-level dot "·"; if three consecutive syllables are separated only by a glide *j only the last two were affected by contraction

changes.name: The first jotation and Kortlandt's compensatory lengthening
changes.description:
The sequences *tj, *dj, *sj, *zj, *rj, *lj, *nj, *čj, and *žj were "jotated" to *tʹ, *dʹ, *š, *ž, *rʼ, *lʹ, *ń, *č, and *ž; if a *Cj sequence was preceded by *s or *z, the latter were affected by jotation as well; as a result of the loss of the glide *j, a short following syllable was lengthened; this lengthening was later on undone by several analogical processes but left an indirect trace in the accent shift according to Ivšić's first law (§ 36)
t, n, č i Ž

changes.name: The change of *ḱtˊ, *x́tˊ to *tˊ
changes.description: The sequences *ḱtˊ, *x́tˊ, resulting from the change of *kt, *xt to *ḱtˊ, *x́tˊ (§ 13), were simplified to *tˊ

changes.name: The change of *dz > *z
changes.description: The affricate *dz, resulting from the change *dʹ > *dz (§ 16), changed to the fricative *z

changes.name: Ivšić's first law
changes.description: The accent shifted from a long syllable not bearing the acute or neoacute tone by one syllable to the left; if the newly accented syllable was long, it received a neoacute tone

changes.name: Ivšić's second law
changes.description: The accent shifted from a jer (*ъ, *ь) by one syllable to the left; if the newly accented syllable was long, it received a neoacute tone

changes.name: The change of *ȳ to *ī
changes.description: The unrounded back vowel *ȳ was fronted to *ī

changes.name: The change of *ъ to *ь
changes.description: The back jers *ъ, *ъ̄  merged with the front jers *ь, *ь̄

changes.name: The change of word-initial *jь- to *i-
changes.description: Word-initial *jь- changed to *i-; the resulting high front vowel was always short

changes.name: Kapović's two-mora law
changes.description: Pretonic long vowels were shortened if they were followed by two or more morae (jers = half a mora, short vowels = one mora, long vowels = two morae)

changes.name: Kapović's four-syllables law
changes.description: In words consisting of four or more syllables that bore the accent on the first syllable, long vowels in the second syllable were shortened

changes.name: The loss of the acute tone
changes.description: Long vowels bearing the acute tone were shortened; in the course of the shortening, the acute tone was lost

changes.name: Three-syllables law
changes.description: Apart from vowels bearing the neoacute tone, long vowels were shortened in words with three or more syllables which did not have a jer (*ъ, ь*) in the paenultima

changes.name: The change of *žr to *ždr
changes.description: A voiced dental plosive was inserted into the sequence *žr: *žr > *ždr

changes.name: The second jer-epenthesis
changes.description: A jer was inserted into sequences of consonant + sonorant + jer that had arisen after the first jer-epenthesis (§ 26) as a result of sound change or analogical change

changes.name: The change of *štˊ to *št and of *ždˊ to *žd
changes.description: The sequences *štʹ, ždʹ changed to *št, žd

changes.name: Denasalization
changes.description: The two nasal vowels were denasalized: *ę, *ę̄ > *e, *ē; *ǫ, *ǭ > *u, *ū

changes.name: The loss of weak jers
changes.description: When counting consecutive syllables containing jers, *ь was lost in odd syllable (so-called weak position); if a weak jer was stressed, the accent shifted to the immediately following syllable

changes.name: Metathesis of word-initial sonorant-fricative sequences
changes.description: Word-initial sequences consisting of sonorant + fricative were metathesized

changes.name: Assimilation in consonant clusters
changes.description: In consonant clusters resulting from the loss of weak jers (§ 49), several assimilations with regard to the place and manner of articulation occurred

changes.name: Simplification of consonant clusters
changes.description: Complex consonant clusters resulting from the loss of weak jers (§ 49) were simplified

changes.name: The change of word-initial *t to *k before oral non-velar plosives
changes.description: The voiceless dental plosive *t changed to its velar counterpart *k before oral non-velar plosives

changes.name: The change of *β to *u before consonants and in word-final position
changes.description: The bilabial fricative *β changed to *u before consonants and in word-final position

changes.name: The change of *ь to *a and of *ь̄ to *ā
changes.description: Jers which had not been lost as a result of the loss of weak jers (§ 49) changed to *a: *ь, *ь̄ > *a, *ā

changes.name: Lengthening of *e and *o before word-final *n and *r
changes.description: The vowels *e and *o were lengthened before word-final *-n and *-r

changes.name: The change of tautosyllabic *ě̄l, *ěl to *īl, *il
changes.description: Jat *ě, *ě̄ was raised to *i, *ī before a tautosyllabic lateral *l: *ěl, *ě̄l > *il, *īl

changes.name: The chage of *ěj to *ij
changes.description: Jat *ě was raised to *i before the glide *j: *ěj > *ij

changes.name: The second l-epenthesis
changes.description: A lateral *l was inserted into sequences consisting of a labial consonant *p, *b, *m, *v and the glide *j that had arisen as a result of the loss of weak jers (§ 49): *pj, *bj, *mj, *vj > *plj, *blj, *mlj, *vlj

changes.name: The change of *ě̄ to *ɩē and of *ě to *ɩe (or *e)
changes.description: Jat *ě, *ě̄  diphthongized to *ɩe, *ɩē unless it was preceded by *j or a sequence of consonant + *r in which case it changed to *e

changes.name: The change of *r’ to *r
changes.description: Palatalized *r’, resulting from jotation (§ 33) was depalatalized to *r

changes.name: The change of syllabic *l̥ to *u and of syllabic *l̥̄ to *ū
changes.description: The syllabic laterals *l̥, *l̥̄ changed to *u, *ū

changes.name: The change of *čr to *cr and of *čr̄ to *cr̄
changes.description: Before rhotics (syllabic or non-syllabic), *č changed to *c: *čr > *cr; *čr̥ > *cr̥; *čr̥̄ > *cr̥̄

changes.name: The change of syllable-final *l to *o
changes.description: Syllable-final *l changed to *o

changes.name: The second jotation
changes.description: As a result of the loss of weak jers (§ 43) and the second l-epenthesis (§ 59), new sequences of dental consonant + j arose; these sequences the target to a second jotation: *tj > *tʹ, *tʹj > *tʹ, *dj > *dʹ, *dʹj > *dʹ, *stj > *štʹ, *zdj > *zdʹ, *lj > *jʹ, *slj > *šlʹ, *nj > *ń, *lɩe > *lʹe,  *nɩe > *ńe; *jt > *tʹ, *jd > *dʹ

changes.name: The change of *ɩe to *je
changes.description: Non-syllabic *ɩ in the diphthong *ɩe changed to *j

changes.name: Lengthening of vowels before sonorant-consonant sequences and before word-final *j
changes.description: Vowels were lengthened before syllable-final sonorants and *j

changes.name: The loss of the neo-acute tone
changes.description: The neo-acute tone merged with the falling tone

changes.name: The Neoštokavian accent shift
changes.description: The accent was shifted by one syllalbe to the left; newly accented syllables received a rising tone which, in this study, is marked by a dot on the line (V̄., V.)

changes.name: The change of *β to *v
changes.description: The bilabial fricative *β changed to the labiodental *v

changes.name: The change of *tˊ to *ć, *dˊ to *đ
changes.description: The palatal plosives *tˊ, *dˊ, resulting from the second Jotation, changed to the affricates *ć, *đ

relations.description: Feeding: The Third palatalization (§ 1) created inputs for Umlaut (§ 2).
Counterfeeding: Had Umlaut (§ 2) occurred prior to the Third palatalization (§ 1), the former change would have created inputs for the latter.
Feeding: The Third palatalization (§ 1) created the inputs for the change *ś > *s (§ 9).
Loanword: The toponym *Bigi > Cr. Bâg was borrowed posterior to the Third palatalization (§ 1), but prior to by Dybo's law (§ 12).
Feeding: The Third palatalization (§ 3) created inputs for the assibiliation (§ 16).
Loanword: The Karelian loanword luota(nen) (cf. PSl. *bjawda) reflects a stage posterior to monophthongization (§ 3), but prior to the change of *ō to *ū (§ 17).

Loanword: The loanwords Gk. sámpsuxon > Lat. *Sa̱mpsicum > Rom. *Sa̱msẹku > Sl. *Sa̱n˙siku > *Sǫ̱˙sьkъ > Cr. Sȕsak and Lat. *Liciniā̱na > Rom. *Lẹkẹnjā̱na > Sl. *Likinā̱˙nu > *Lьkьńa̱nъ > *Lakńa̱n > Cr. Làkljan were borrowed posterior to the Third palatalization (§ 3), but prior to the loss of the acute tone (§ 43).
Feeding: The umlaut of *aj to *ej (§ 2) created inputs for monophthongization (§ 3) of *ej to *ī.
Bleeding: The umlaut of *aj to *ej (§ 2) withdrew inputs from the monophthongization of *aj to *ē (§ 3).
The umlaut of *ā to *ē (§ 2) created inputs for the depalatalization of *ē to *ā (§ 4).
Bleeding: the monophthongization of *ēj to *ī (§ 2) withdrew inputs from the depalatalization of *ē to *ā (§ 4).
Naturalness: It seems more natural to assume that the monophthongization of *aw, *āw, *ew, *ēw to *ō (§ 3) occurred prior to the narrowing of *w to *β (§ 6).
Feeding: The monophthongization of *aj, *āj to *ē (§ 3) created inputs for the Second palatalization (§ 7).
Bleeding: The monophthongization of *aw, *āw, *ew, *ēw to *ō (§ 3) withdrew inputs from the l-epenthesis (§ 8) in cases where the original diphthong was followed by *j.
Feeding: The Monophthongization of *aw, *āw, *ew, *ēw to *ō (§ 3) created inputs for the change of *ō to *ū (§ 17).
Loanword: The Toponym Čak. Ma̱jsan was borrowed from Rom. *Ma̱jsẹmu (< Lat. Ma̱ximus) posterior to Monophthongization (§ 3), but prior to the change of *i to *ь (§ 25).
Feeding: Monophthongization (§ 3) created inputs for the shortening of word-final long vowels (§ 31).
Feeding: Monophthongization (§ 3) created inputs for Kapović's Two-Mora law (§ 41).
Feeding: Monophthongization (§ 3) for the shortening accompanying the loss of the acute tone (§ 43).
Loanword: Cr. òvrata was borrowed from Rom. *aurā̱ta (< Lat. aurā̱ta) posterior to the monophthongization (§ 3), but prior to the shortening accompanying the loss of the acute tone and (§ 43).
Feeding: Monophthongization (§ 3) created inputs for the Three-Syllable law (§ 44).
Feeding: Monophthongization (§ 3) created inputs for the shortening of vowels preceding laterals affected by the change of syllable-final *l to *o (§ 64).

Counterbleeding: Had the shortening of word-final *ēn to *en (§ 22) occurred prior to Depalatalization (§ 4), the former change would have created inputs for the latter, cf. PSl. *-jān > *-jēn > *-jān > -jǭ > Cr. -ju and not PSl. *-jān > *-jēn > **-jen > **-ję etc.
Naturalness: It is more plausible to assume that w-prothesis (§ 6) occurred before the narrowing of *w to *β (§ 6).
Loanword: Cr. O̱.ciń was borrowed from Rom *Ọlkẹ̱̄nʼu (< Lat. Olci̱nium) posterior to w-prothesis (§ 5), but prior to the Second palatalization of *k to *tʹ (> *c) (§ 7).
Naturalness: It is more plausibel to assume that w-prothesis (§ 6) occurred prior to the delabialization of *ū to *ȳ (§ 15).
Feeding: w-prothesis (§ 5) created inputs for the change of *β to *u before consonants and in word-final position (§ 54).
Loanword: Cr. Ca̱.vtat was borrowed from Rom. *Kiβẹtā̱tẹ (< Lat. Cīvitātem) posterior to the narrowing of *w to *β (§ 6), but prior to the Second palatalization of *k to *tʹ (> *c) (§ 7).
Feeding: The narrowing of *w to *β (§ 5) created inputs for the change of *β to *u before consonants and in word-final position (§ 54).
Feeding: The narrowing of *w to *β (§ 5) created inputs for the change of *β to *v (§ 70).
Feeding: The Second palatalization (§ 7) created inputs for the change of *ś to *s (§ 9).
Loanword: The toponym Cr. Bā̱g was borrowed from Rom. βẹ̱gẹ (< Lat. Ve̱gium) posterior to the Third palatalization (§ 1), but prior to Dybo's law (§ 12).
Feeding: The Second palatalization (§ 3) created inputs for the assibiliation (§ 16).
Counterbleedin: Had the Second liquid metathesis (§ 20) occurred prior to the Second palatalization (§ 7), the former change would have withdrawn inputs from the latter.
Loanword: The toponym Cr. krijē̱ša was borrowed from Rom. *ke̱rsja (< Lat. *cere̱sea) posterior to the Second palatalization (§ 7), but prior to the First jotation of *sj to *š (§ 33).

Loanword: The loanwords Cr. krijē̱ša and Ka̱rin were borrowed from Rom. *ke̱rsja (< Lat. *cere̱sea) and *Kẹrī̱nu (< Lat. Quirī̱nus), respectively, posterior to the Second palatalization (§ 7), but prior to the operation of Ivšić's first law (§ 36).
Loanword: The toponym Cr. Làkljan was borrowed from Rom. *Lẹkẹnjā̱na (< Lat. *Liciniā̱na) posterior to the Second palatalization (§ 7), but prior to the loss of the acute tone (§ 43).
Loanword: The Karelian loanword luota(nen) (cf. PSl. *bljawda) reflects a stage posterior to l-epenthesis (§ 8), but prior to the change of *ō to *ū (§ 17).
Feeding: l-epenthesis (§ 8) created inputs for the First jotation (§ 33).

Naturalness: The change of *ś > *s (§ 9) most probably occurred independently and before assibiliation (§ 16) since it would be difficult to reconcile the dvelopment of the affricates and fricatives under one rule.
Counterbleeding: Had Meillet's metatony (§ 11) occurred prior to the First liquid metathesis (§ 10), the former change would have created inputs for the latter.

Naturalness: The assumption of a relative chronology that places the change of *a to *o (§ 23) before the First Liquid metathesis (§ 10), requires the assumption of an unatural change of tautosyllabic *or to rā.
Feeding: First liquid metathesis (§ 10) created inputs for the shortening accompanying the loss of the acute tone (§ 43).
Bleeding: The First liquid metathesis of tautosyllabic *al to *lā (§ 10) withdrew inputs from the vocalization of syllable final *l to *o (§ 64).
Counterbleeding: Had the rise of stress in unaccented accentual units (§ 30) occurred prior to Meillet's metatony (§ 11), the former change would have withdrawn inputs from the latter.
Bleeding: Meillet's metatony (§ 11) withdrew inputs from the shortening of vowels accompanying the loss of the acute tone (§ 43).
Loanword: The loanword Cr. lo̱tika was borrowed from Rom. *laçtū̱ka (< Lat. lactū̱ca) posterior to Dybo's law (§ 12), but prior to the change of *kt, *xt to *t (§ 14).
Loanword: The loanword Cr. lo̱tika was borrowed from Rom. *laçtū̱ka (< Lat. lactū̱ca) posterior to Dybo's law (§ 12), but prior to the delabialization of *ū to *ȳ (§ 15).
Loanword: The loanword Cr. lo̱tika was borrowed from Rom. *laçtū̱ka (< Lat. lactū̱ca) posterior to Dybo's law (§ 12), but prior to the change of *a to *o (§ 23).
Loanword: The loanword Cr. Krbe̱la was borrowed form Rom. Krẹβe̱llu (< Lat. *Cribe̱llum) posterior to Dybo's law (§ 12), but prior to the change of *i to *ь and *u to *ъ (§ 25).

Counterfeeding: Had the First jer-epenthesis (§ 26) occurred prior to Dybo's law (§ 12), the former change would have created inputs for the latter, cf. PSl. *a̱gni > *ogńь̱ > *ogьńь̱ > Cr. o̱gań and not PSl. *a̱gni > *o̱gńь > **o̱gьńь > **ogь̱ńь etc.
Counterfeeding: Had the accentuation of unaccented accentual units (§ 30) occurred prior to Dybo's law (§ 12), the former change created inputs for the latter.
Feeding: Dybo's law (§ 12) created inputs for Kortlandt's compensatory lengthening (§ 33).
Feeding: Dybo's law (§ 12) created inputs for Ivšić's first law (§ 36).

Loanword: The loanwords Cr. Skra̱.din and Ka̱rin were borrowed from Rom. *Skardū̱na (< Lat. Scardō̱na) and *Kẹrī̱nu (< Lat. Quirī̱nus), respectively, posterior to Dybo's law (§ 12), but prior to Ivšić's first law (§ 36).
Feeding: Dybo's law (§ 12) created inputs for Ivšić's second law (§ 37).
Bleeding: Dybo's law (§ 12) withdrew inputs from Ivšić's second law (§ 37), cf. PSl. *gawmi̱na > *gūmьno̱ > Cr. gu̱.mno.
Feeding: Dybo's law (§ 12) created inputs for Kapović's Two-Mora law (§ 41).
Feeding: Dybo's law (§ 12) for the shortening of long vowels accompanying the loss of the acute tone (§ 43) in dialects in which the latter change was limited to accented syllables.
Bleeding: Dybo's law (§ 12) withdrew inputs from Three-syllables law (§ 44).
Feeding: Dybo's law (§ 12) created inputs for the Neo-Štokavian accent shift (§ 69).
Naturalness: The reverse relative chronology would require restricting the simplification of *kt to *t (§ 14) to the position before non-front vowels which would be unatural.
Feeding: The change of *kt to *kʹtʹ (§ 13) created inputs for the change of *kʹtʹ to tʹ (§ 34).
Counterfeeding: Had the loss of weak jers (§ 49) occurred prior to the change of *kt to *kʹtʹ (§ 13), the former change would have created inputs for the latter.
Loanword: The loanwords Cr. puč and Žuńь were borrowed from Lat. puteus and Lat. Junius, respectively, posterior to the change of *ū to *ȳ (§ 15), but prior to the assibiliation (§ 16).
Counterfeeding: Had the change of *ō to *ū (§ 17) occurred prior ot the change of  *ū to *ȳ (§ 15), the former change would have created inputs for the latter.
Loanword: The toponym Cr. Žuńь was borrowed from Lat. Junius posterior to the change of *ū to *ȳ (§ 15), but prior to the change of *dž to *ž (§ 18).

Loanword: The name Tagazino (ca. 897 AD), which presents a misinterpretation of CSl. *taga sȳnъ, reflects a stage posterior to the change of *ū to *ȳ (§ 15), but prior to the change of *a to *o (§ 23).
Feeding: The change of *ū to *ȳ (§ 15) created inputs for the shortening of word-final *ȳ to *y (§ 31).
Bleeding: The change of *ū to *ȳ (§ 15) withrew inputs from the shortening of word-final *ū to *u (§ 31).
Feeding: The change of *ū to *ȳ (§ 15) created inputs for the shortening of long vowels accompanying the loss of the acute tone (§ 43).
Feeding: The change of *ū to *ȳ (§ 15) created inputs for the Three-Syllable law (§ 44).
Feeding: The change of *ū to *ȳ (§ 15) created inputs for the shortening of long vowels accompanying the vocalization of syllable-final *l (§ 64).
Counterfeeding: Had the first jotation (§ 33) occurred prior to the assibilation of *tʹ to *c and *dʹ to *dz (§ 33), the former change would have created inputs for the latter.
Feeding: The assibilation of *dʹ to *dz (§ 16) created inputs for the change of *dz to *z (§ 35).
Counterfeeding: Had the first jotation (§ 65) occurred prior to the assibilation of *tʹ to *c and *dʹ to *dz (§ 33), the former change would have created inputs for the latter.

Loanwords: The toponym Cr. Žuńь was borrowed from Lat. Junius posterior to the change of *ō to *ū (§ 17) because Rom. *ū was already identified with this vowel and not with PSl. *ū (> CSl. ȳ, § 15), but prior to the change of *dž to *ž (§ 18) because Rom. *dz was still substituted by Sl. *dž (> *ž). The loanwoard iupanus written in Romance orthography (<i> before a vowel = dž) reflects a stage at which *ō had already change to *ū (§ 17) while *dž was still present.
Feeding: The change of *ō to *ū (§ 17) created inputs for the shortening of word-final long vowels (§ 31).
Counterfeeding: Had contraction (§ 32) occurred prior to the change of *ō to *ū (§ 17), the former change would have created inputs for the latter.
Feeding: The change of *ō to *ū (§ 17) created inputs for the Kapovićs two-mora law (§ 41).
Feeding: The change of *ō to *ū (§ 17) created inputs for the shortening accompanying the loss of the acute tone (§ 43).
